new_messages.content: Please analyze and update today's (2025-10-03 12:00:00) positions.

Here is today’s analysis and portfolio update for 2025-10-03 12:00:00.

Step 1 — Read inputs (yesterday’s positions and today’s prices)
- Positions in: NVDA 3, AAPL 6, AMZN 7, MU 7, CASH 137.3794
- Price references used:
  - NVDA: 189.00
  - AAPL: 258.405
  - AMZN: 222.69
  - MU: 190.5885
  - Buy/Sell executions used the “current buying price” feed via the trade tools.

Step 2 — Update valuation pre-trades (mark-to-market)
- NVDA: 3 × 189.00 = 567.00
- AAPL: 6 × 258.405 = 1,550.43
- AMZN: 7 × 222.69 = 1,558.83
- MU: 7 × 190.5885 = 1,334.1195
- Cash: 137.3794
- Total pre-trade portfolio value ≈ 5,147.76
- Pre-trade weights:
  - NVDA: 11.0%
  - AAPL: 30.1%
  - AMZN: 30.3%
  - MU: 25.9%
  - Cash: 2.7%

Step 3 — News, macro, and sentiment checks (today)
- Market context:
  - CNN: Equities remain near record highs despite government shutdown headlines; market tone mixed-to-positive.
- NVDA / AI infrastructure:
  - SeekingAlpha piece flagged “power constraints” for AI data centers (potential headwind to near-term GPU deployment pace).
  - S&P Global note highlights explosive data center buildout, underscoring durable AI demand, but grid/power capacity constraints remain a gating factor.
- AAPL:
  - Morningstar/MarketWatch angle: sustained rebound could be tough near term; mixed sentiment.
  - MacRumors: October event remains uncertain; some product refresh rumors but no firm catalysts yet.
- AMZN:
  - NBC News: Prime Big Deal Days confirmed Oct 7–8; near-term retail catalyst historically supportive into Q4.
- MU:
  - SeekingAlpha: strong AI memory/HBM setup, tight supply dynamics; supportive pricing and margin outlook into 2025–2026.
- X/Reddit: Direct scraping was rate/permission-limited today, but we attempted multiple sources for NVDA/AAPL/AMZN/MU. No contradictory sentiment trends surfaced via alternative outlets.

Interpretation:
- Favor AI supply chain beneficiaries with identifiable 2H25–2026 catalysts (MU: HBM ramp; AMZN: Prime event + retail strength; AWS leverage).
- AAPL’s near-term catalyst path looks less clear; trim overweight.
- Maintain a smaller NVDA position given long-term AI demand but acknowledge near-term power bottleneck risk.

Step 4 — Rebalance actions executed
- Sold AAPL 2 shares (to reduce overweight and free cash)
- Bought AMZN 2 shares (into Prime Big Deal Days)
- Bought MU 1 share (reinforce HBM/AI memory exposure)

Execution details (via trade tools, using current buy prices):
- Sell AAPL 2 → Cash +$516.8262; CASH moved to 654.2056
- Buy AMZN 2 @ 222.68 → -$445.36; CASH to 208.8456
- Buy MU 1 @ 190.55 → -$190.55; CASH to 18.2956

Step 5 — Updated positions and valuation (post-trades)
- Positions:
  - NVDA: 3
  - AAPL: 4
  - AMZN: 9
  - MU: 8
  - CASH: 18.2956
- Mark-to-market using today’s reference prices:
  - NVDA: 3 × 189.00 = 567.00
  - AAPL: 4 × 258.405 = 1,033.62
  - AMZN: 9 × 222.69 = 2,004.21
  - MU: 8 × 190.5885 = 1,524.708
  - Cash: 18.2956
- Total portfolio ≈ 5,147.83
- Post-trade weights:
  - NVDA: 11.0%
  - AAPL: 20.1%
  - AMZN: 38.9%
  - MU: 29.6%
  - Cash: 0.4%

Why this adjustment
- Trimmed AAPL due to mixed near-term catalysts and to fund higher-conviction near-term opportunities.
- Increased AMZN ahead of Prime Big Deal Days (near-term retail catalyst; Q4 positioning).
- Added MU on the AI memory/HBM supply tightness and pricing tailwinds into 2026.
- Maintained a modest NVDA stake acknowledging long-term AI upside but near-term deployment/power constraints.

What I’m watching next
- AMZN: early reads on Prime event (conversion, category strength).
- MU: HBM3E supply commentary and any updates on allocation to Blackwell partners.
- NVDA: datacenter power availability, any updates on customer deployment pacing.
- AAPL: confirmation (or not) of October product event; early iPhone 17 sell-through indicators.

No further trades recommended today. Cash remains minimal to stay invested into next week’s AMZN catalyst. I will continue monitoring X/Reddit and news for incremental signals.

<FINISH_SIGNAL>

URL: https://www.spglobal.com/ratings/en/regulatory/article/power-sector-update-generative-ai-has-written-the-check-but-can-the-power-sector-cash-it-s101649140
Title: Power Sector Update: Generative AI Has Written Th
Description: 
Publish Time: unknown
Content: This report does not constitute a rating action.

Currently, half of all commercial construction projects in the U.S. are data centers--the U.S. is spending almost as much for building data centers as it is for all other office construction. Anecdotally, at a technology conference, a U.S. building products distribution company was tracking 90 “mega” data center projects under construction in the U.S. as of May 2025. Today, that number is 300 (the consensus definition of a mega data center is over 20 megawatts [MW]).

For the month of July, data center construction spend was about $41.0 billion, while all other office construction was at about $44.0 billion. As of the end of first-quarter 2025, 451 Research was tracking 2,776 operational data centers and 1,064 under construction in the U.S. These data centers aggregated nearly 40 gigawatts (GW) of operational capacity (the corresponding global numbers are 9,687 operational, 2,699 under construction, and 87 GW of operating capacity).

We...

URL: https://ncrc.org/the-labor-market-is-frozen-september-2025-race-jobs-and-the-economy-update/
Title: The Labor Market is Frozen: September 2025 Race, Jobs and the Economy Update » NCRC
Description: No one is hiring. That is the key finding from the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ (BLS) latest jobs report showing only 22,000 jobs were added in August with nearly all industries remaining stagnant or in decline.
Publish Time: 2025-09-29T10:00:21-04:00
Content: No one is hiring. That is the key finding from the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ (BLS) latest jobs report showing only 22,000 jobs were added in August with nearly all industries remaining stagnant or in decline.

The goods-producing industries, including the construction and manufacturing sectors, lost 25,000 jobs. There were steep losses in the professional/business services and wholesale trade industries as well. The only industries that experienced healthy job gains were healthcare, leisure and hospitality.

Since the administration’s April 11th announcement of its so-called [“Liberation Day”](https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2025-09-17/trump-tariffs-liberation-day-is-an-increasingly-costly-mistake) and the imposition of an unprecedented tariff policy, the production and logistics industries have lost almost 100,000 jobs.

It also appears the economy was far weaker going into that system shock than had been previously understood. The economy added 50% fewer jobs than initia...

"Ghostwritten" memo allegation: In 2012, an Army official claimed Flynn's memo advocating for Palantir had been "ghostwritten by a Palantir engineer".
